awd_titl_txt: An investigation of the impact of culture and experience on reasoning about complex ecological phenomena among students from diverse backgrounds
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative research, approaches and resources for use in a variety of settings. The project will conduct research designed to deepen our fundamental knowledge about culture, experience, and ecosystems cognition and to develop innovative practices and approaches to support learning about changing ecological systems and environmental decision making. Work on cultural differences in the production of complex systems knowledge is severely lacking. This gap in knowledge may contribute to the continued reproduction of inequities in science education. More broadly findings from this project will have clear implications for theories of cognitive development, especially those pertaining to how knowledge is shaped by culture and experience. Focusing on ecosystems may represent an opportunity to not only increase engagement and achievement in science among non-dominant communities and Native youth specifically, but also advance effective learning for all communities. The primary deliverables for the project are conference presentations and research publications. However, the project will also develop additional resources freely available to researchers, educators, and the general public. These will include summer curricular materials and teaching tools, professional development workshops, practitioner briefs about research findings that can be used in professional development workshops and shared share more broadly, and evaluation reports.

A deeper understanding of cultural influences on conceptions of the natural world can serve to advance the educational needs of children, including children from diverse linguistic and cultural backgrounds. Project research will include two interrelated series of studies designed to expand knowledge about human cognition of complex ecosystems and the affordances of informal STEM learning environments in developing and supporting the critical 21st century skill of ecological systems level reasoning. The first consists of a series of experiments focused on ecological cognition and the role of humans in nature. The second consists of design-based research interventions in informal settings, summer workshops for youth and the communities, focused on ecological systems level thinking and socio-environmental decision making. The project will recruit and engage both child and adult participants from two broad cultural communities, Native Americans and European Americans living in urban and suburban communities, in part because it affords a sharp test of human-nature relations. Sampling from two different urban communities will avoid simple Native-non-Native comparative binaries and to conduct Native-to-Native comparative analysis. Based on results from this, the project will result in: 1) foundational knowledge about human learning and reasoning and ecosystems and environmental decision making, 2) culturally responsive models of learning and practice about complex ecosystems for indoors and outdoors informal learning environments, and 3) insights about research-practice-community partnerships. One important objective of the research is to broaden participation and close opportunity gaps for under-represented groups in STEM fields broadly and more specifically for Indigenous people. Members of Indigenous communities, who provide strong role models for other aspiring scholars, will be involved as postdoctoral fellows, research assistants and graduate fellows.

por.por_cntn:
Goals. This project aims to (1) deepen our fundamental knowledge about culture and ecosystems cognition, (2) develop innovative practices to support learning about ecosystems, and (3) broaden participation for under-represented groups in STEM fields, especially Indigenous people.

Our project produced three main outcomes: 1) knowledge concerning reasoning about ecosystems and environmental decision making, 2) culturally responsive models of ecosystem cognition, and 3) insights about research-practice-community partnerships.

 

Ecological Cognition. Focusing on ecosystems and the role of humans within them represents an opportunity to increase engagement and achievement in science among non-dominant communities and Native youth specifically. The cultural influences on ecosystems cognition we observed can be used to identify specific practices and supports for ecological education.

A critical facet of thinking about the biological world is the place of humans within it. We have found that some cultural groups (e.g., European American) tend to think of nature as separate from humans. Other cultural groups (e.g., Native Americans) see themselves as a part of nature. These differences are observed in surveys and a range of cognitive tasks. They are even reflected in artifacts such as children’s books, and in science-related images in science textbooks and Google images.

As one example we asked Native and Non-Native (predominately European-American) children and adults to sort pictures of scenes into whether they represent “Nature” or “Not-Nature.” The pictures varied in how evident human artifacts were (e.g. buildings, cars) and whether humans were present. There were two significant results: 1. Native participants sorted more cards into “Nature” than Non-Native participants 2. The presence of humans decreased the likelihood that Non-Native participants sorted a scene into “Nature” but increased the likelihood that Native participants did.

More striking is data showing that Non-Native participants hold multiple models of human-nature relationships. Evidence comes from a questionnaire we gave with items focused on ecosystems and human engagement with them (e.g. “deer hunting as a way to manage deer overpopulation”). One key result was that both Native and Non-Native samples strongly agree with the statement “Humans are part of ecosystems.”

This finding for Non-Native participants suggested a distinction whereby implicitly, humans are not part of ecosystems, but for directly and explicit queries, humans are included in ecosystems. An online survey tested whether the prime (“Humans are part of ecosystems”) would affect answers to other questions about human-ecosystems relations. We created two versions of the survey. Version A included the priming statement as the 3rd statement of 17 while Version B inverted the statements’ order. Our survey yielded reliable priming effects. For example, participants given Version A were reliably more likely to disagree with the statement, “Urban environments can’t really be considered ecosystem,” than participants given Version B and more likely to agree with statements involving humans playing an active role in ecosystems (e.g. deer hunting to manage deer overpopulation). These priming effects have strong implications for environmental education and environmental decision making.

 

Research-Practice-Community Partnerships.  We continue to disseminate learning materials, which we make available to our participating Family ISTEAM participants and our larger community contacts. They, in turn, bring knowledge back to their organizations, e.g. the American Indian Education Program in Chicago Public Schools. Family learning materials and other resources are posted on our public website (IndigenousSTEAM.org) allowing for broader dissemination.  Finally, multiple communities beyond our focal communities have requested our professional development program to implement our model of science education.    

 

Broadening Participation.   Members of Indigenous communities have increasingly become involved in our project as Pls, postdoctoral fellows, undergraduate RAs, and graduate fellows (two Native-American graduate students will finish their PhDs this year). Our project also serves to point to the value of research for Native-American communities and provides strong role models for other Native scholars. 

 

Summary. This project contributes to improving science education by its focus on Native-American epistemological orientations and their consequences for science-related practices. We 'ground truth' these observations by design studies of culturally-based science learning and supported by both qualitative and quantitative observations.

Our findings have clear impacts on theories of conceptual development, especially those pertaining to how children's and adults' existing knowledge is shaped by cultural models. Our project has been very productive in terms of publishing journal articles and book chapters, publicizing our findings at scientific meetings and community workshops, developing culturally appropriate curriculum materials, and in building research capacity in Native American communities.  

Our finding that people may hold implicit models of human-nature relations (namely, that humans are outside of nature and not part of it) that contradict their explicit beliefs (e.g. they strongly agree that humans ARE part of ecosystems) is a finding that carries significant practical implications, because eliciting these explicit beliefs directly affects judgments about human action associated with ecosystems. It is also important that science education take into account the cultural origins of implicit models of human-nature relations.
